metadata.project: Lewis & Clark College Reading Series Archive
metadata.notes: All writers collected. 8 entries flagged for review (low confidence or industry professionals).

writers.name: Michael Ondaatje
writers.bio: Sri Lankan-born Canadian poet and novelist whose work blends myth, history, and lyrical prose. His novel The English Patient won the Booker Prize and was adapted into an Academy Award-winning film.
notableWorks: In the Skin of a Lion
The Collected Works of Billy the Kid

writers.name: Natalie Diaz
writers.bio: Mojave American poet, language activist, and MacArthur Fellow. Her collection Postcolonial Love Poem won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for Poetry. She is enrolled in the Gila River Indian Community and works on Mojave language preservation.
notableWorks: When My Brother Was an Aztec

writers.name: Nikky Finney
writers.bio: South Carolina-born poet whose work explores African American history, civil rights, and Southern heritage. Her collection Head Off & Split won the 2011 National Book Award for Poetry. She is a founding member of the Affrilachian Poets.
notableWorks: Love Child's Hotbed of Occasional Poetry

writers.name: Aamina Ahmad
writers.bio: Pakistani-American novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut novel The Return of Faraz Ali won the L.A. Times Art Seidenbaum Award and was named a Best Book of the Year by The New York Times and NPR.

writers.name: Adam Bradley
writers.bio: Literary scholar and Lewis & Clark College alum who pioneered the academic study of hip-hop lyrics as poetry. Professor at UCLA and founding director of the Laboratory for Race & Popular Culture.
notableWorks: Book of Rhymes: The Poetics of Hip Hop

writers.name: Ada Limón
writers.bio: The 24th U.S. Poet Laureate and the first Latina to hold the position. Her collection The Carrying won the National Book Critics Circle Award, and she was appointed to a historic two-year second term as laureate.

writers.name: Alan Shapiro
writers.bio: American poet and William R. Kenan Jr. Distinguished Professor at UNC Chapel Hill. His collection Night of the Republic was a finalist for both the National Book Award and the Griffin Poetry Prize.

writers.name: Alexia Arthurs
writers.bio: Jamaican-American fiction writer and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut story collection How to Love a Jamaican won the Paris Review's Plimpton Prize and explores the Jamaican immigrant experience.

writers.name: Alexis Smith
writers.bio: Pacific Northwest novelist whose debut Glaciers was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Her second novel Marrow Island won the Pacific Northwest Booksellers Association Award and a Lambda Literary Award.

writers.name: Alix Ohlin
writers.bio: Canadian novelist and short story writer. Her novel Dual Citizens was shortlisted for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, and her collection We Want What We Want won the Lambda Literary Award for Bisexual Literature.

writers.name: Ama Codjoe
writers.bio: American poet and dancer. Her collection Bluest Nude won the 2023 Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize and a Whiting Award. She was appointed the second Poet-in-Residence at the Guggenheim Museum.

writers.name: Anis Mojgani
writers.bio: Spoken word poet and Oregon's 10th Poet Laureate (2020-2024). He won back-to-back National Poetry Slam titles in 2005-2006, and his book The Feather Room was a National Book Award nominee.
awards: Academy of American Poets Laureate Fellowship

writers.name: Anna Keesey
writers.bio: Oregon-based novelist and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her debut Little Century, set in 1900 Central Oregon, was praised by The Washington Post as a work about 'who will inherit the earth.'
awards: National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship

writers.name: Arthur Bradford
writers.bio: American writer and filmmaker whose debut story collection Dogwalker was praised by David Sedaris as the work of 'the most outlandish and energetic writer I can think of.' His stories have appeared in McSweeney's and Esquire.

writers.name: Betsy Amster
writers.bio: Literary agent and former editor at Pantheon and Vintage Books. She founded Betsy Amster Literary Enterprises in 1992 and frequently teaches at UCLA Extension's Writers Program.

writers.name: Brenda Hillman
writers.bio: Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets and ecopoet whose tetralogy on the classical elements culminated in Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire, winner of the Griffin Poetry Prize. Married to Pulitzer winner Robert Hass.
notableWorks: Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire

writers.name: Catherine Barnett
writers.bio: New York-based poet whose collection The Game of Boxes won the James Laughlin Award. Human Hours was a New York Times Best Poetry selection and won the Believer Book Award.
notableWorks: Solutions for the Problem of Bodies in Space

writers.name: Catherine Ellis
writers.bio: Information not found. May be a local/regional writer or the name may need verification.

writers.name: Charif Shanahan
writers.bio: Moroccan-Irish American poet and Northwestern professor. His collection Trace Evidence won the Lambda Literary Award and was longlisted for the National Book Award. Recipient of the Whiting Award.
notableWorks: Into Each Room We Enter without Knowing

writers.name: Charles Baxter
writers.bio: American novelist and short story writer whose novel The Feast of Love was a National Book Award finalist. Winner of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story.
awards: Rea Award for the Short Story

writers.name: Christine Deavel
writers.bio: Seattle poet and former co-owner of Open Books: A Poem Emporium. Her collection Woodnote won the 2012 Washington State Book Award for poetry and the Dorothy Brunsman Poetry Prize.

writers.name: Claire Vaye Watkins
writers.bio: American author whose debut story collection Battleborn won The Story Prize and the Dylan Thomas Prize. Named a National Book Foundation '5 under 35' honoree and recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship.
notableWorks: I Love You but I've Chosen Darkness

writers.name: Consuelo Wise
writers.bio: Guatemalan-American poet and Lewis & Clark alumna (BA '09). Her debut book-length poem b o y is an elegy written in fragments about the loss of her two brothers.

writers.name: Corey Van Landingham
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark alumna whose debut Antidote won the Ohio State University Press/The Journal Wheeler Prize. Her collection Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens won the Levis Reading Prize.
notableWorks: Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens

writers.name: D.A. Powell
writers.bio: American poet whose book Useless Landscape won the National Book Critics Circle Award. His trilogy on the AIDS epidemic (Tea, Lunch, Cocktails) established him as a major voice in contemporary poetry.
notableWorks: Useless Landscape, or A Guide for Boys

writers.name: David Baker
writers.bio: Poet of the American Midwest who served as poetry editor of the Kenyon Review for over 25 years. Won the Theodore Roethke Memorial Poetry Prize for Never-Ending Birds.

writers.name: Derrick Austin
writers.bio: Poet whose debut Trouble the Water was selected by Mary Szybist for the A. Poulin Jr. Poetry Prize. His collection Tenderness won the Isabella Gardner Poetry Award.

writers.name: Don Waters
writers.bio: Reno-born fiction writer whose debut collection Desert Gothic won the Iowa Short Fiction Award. Praised by Percival Everett for prose 'as sneaky as the landscape it depicts.'

writers.name: Elena Passarello
writers.bio: Essayist and actor whose Animals Strike Curious Poses was a New York Times Editor's Choice. First woman to win the Stella Screaming Contest in New Orleans and recipient of a Whiting Award.

writers.name: Emily Chenoweth
writers.bio: Portland novelist and former Publishers Weekly fiction editor. Her debut Hello Goodbye explores a family's struggle with loss. Also ghostwrites YA novels with James Patterson under the name Emily Raymond.

writers.name: Emily Wilson
writers.bio: British-American classicist and the first woman to translate Homer's Odyssey into English. Her translation became a cultural landmark and earned her a MacArthur Fellowship.
notableWorks: The Greatest Empire: A Life of Seneca

writers.name: Endi Bogue Hartigan
writers.bio: Portland poet and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate. Her collection Pool [5 choruses] won the Omnidawn Open Poetry Book Prize, and One Sun Storm won the Colorado Prize for Poetry.

writers.name: Eric Lundgren
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark alumnus whose Borgesian debut The Facades was a Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers pick and finalist for the William Saroyan International Prize.

writers.name: Eric Schlosser
writers.bio: Investigative journalist whose Fast Food Nation became a landmark exposé of the American food industry. His Command and Control was a Pulitzer Prize finalist.

writers.name: Erin Ergenbright
writers.bio: Portland writer, Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate, and co-founder of the Loggernaut Reading Series. Has taught at Lewis & Clark and co-authored The Ex-Boyfriend Cookbook.

writers.name: Fady Joudah
writers.bio: Palestinian-American poet and physician whose debut The Earth in the Attic won the Yale Series of Younger Poets. His translations of Mahmoud Darwish introduced Palestinian poetry to American readers.
notableWorks: Footnotes in the Order of Disappearance

writers.name: Geneviève Hudson
writers.bio: Portland fiction writer and essayist whose novel Boys of Alabama was a finalist for the Oregon Book Award and shortlisted for the Stonewall Book Award. Recipient of MacDowell and Fulbright fellowships.
notableWorks: A Little in Love with Everyone

writers.name: Geoffrey G. O'Brien
writers.bio: Poet and UC Berkeley professor whose meditative work explores perception and public space. Also teaches for the Prison University Project at San Quentin.

writers.name: Gillian Conoley
writers.bio: Poet-in-Residence at Sonoma State University and founder-editor of VOLT Magazine. Her collection Tall Stranger was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award.

writers.name: Hamid Ismailov
writers.bio: Uzbek novelist exiled to the UK whose works remain banned in Uzbekistan. Former BBC World Service Writer in Residence. His novel The Devils' Dance won the EBRD Literary Prize.

writers.name: Henry Carlisle
writers.bio: San Francisco-born novelist descended from Nantucket whalers. With his wife Olga, he smuggled and translated Solzhenitsyn's manuscripts. The Jonah Man fictionalizes the Essex disaster.
notableWorks: Voyage to the First of December

writers.name: Hillel Schwartz
writers.bio: Cultural historian and poet whose Never Satisfied traces America's obsession with dieting. Also authored The Culture of the Copy and Making Noise, and translates Korean poetry.
notableWorks: Never Satisfied: A Cultural History of Diets, Fantasies and Fat

writers.name: Ismet Prcic
writers.bio: Bosnian-American novelist who fled his war-torn homeland in 1996. His debut Shards won the Sue Kaufman Prize, LA Times Art Seidenbaum Award, and Oregon Book Award.
awards: Sue Kaufman Prize for First Fiction

writers.name: J. Hillis Miller
writers.bio: Major American literary critic and last surviving member of the Yale School of Deconstruction. Wrote over 50 books analyzing literature through deconstructionist principles.

writers.name: Jacques J. Rancourt
writers.bio: Maine-raised, San Francisco-based poet and former Stegner Fellow. His debut Novena won the Lena-Miles Wever Todd Prize and explores coming-of-age and coming out.

writers.name: James Anderson
writers.bio: Reed College graduate whose debut The Never-Open Desert Diner was praised by The Washington Post as 'outstanding in every regard.' Also co-produced an award-winning documentary on Tibetan refugees.

writers.name: Jane Wong
writers.bio: Chinese American poet whose How to Not Be Afraid of Everything was longlisted for the PEN/Voelcker Award. Also authored the memoir Meet Me Tonight in Atlantic City about growing up in her family's restaurant.
notableWorks: Meet Me Tonight in Atlantic City
How to Not Be Afraid of Everything

writers.name: Jennifer Grotz
writers.bio: Director of the Bread Loaf Writers' Conferences and Guggenheim Fellow. Her translations of Jerzy Ficowski won the PEN Award for Best Book of Poetry in Translation.

writers.name: James Galvin
writers.bio: Iowa Writers' Workshop faculty member whose Resurrection Update was a finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Award. His prose meditation The Meadow chronicles life on the Wyoming-Colorado border.

writers.name: Joe Wilkins
writers.bio: Montana-raised writer now at Linfield University in Oregon. His poetry collection When We Were Birds won the Oregon Book Award; his novel The Entire Sky won the Montana Book Award.
notableWorks: Fall Back Down When I Die

writers.name: John Beer
writers.bio: Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate whose The Waste Land and Other Poems won the Norma Farber First Book Award. Formerly Robert Lax's literary assistant on the Greek island of Patmos.
notableWorks: The Waste Land and Other Poems

writers.name: John Casteen
writers.bio: Virginia poet and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate who teaches at University of Virginia. Former custom furniture builder whose poems explore physical work and Appalachian landscape.

writers.name: John Farrell
writers.bio: Professor of Literature at Claremont McKenna College. His book The Varieties of Authorial Intention has been called 'potentially the most important statement of literary theory to have emerged in this century.'

writers.name: John Freeman Gill
writers.bio: Yale summa cum laude graduate and longtime New York Times contributor. His debut The Gargoyle Hunters was a Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers Selection, praised by Annie Proulx as 'extraordinary.'

writers.name: John Marshall
writers.bio: Pacific Northwest poet and co-owner of Open Books poetry bookstore in Seattle. Commentator on regional literary history.

writers.name: Jon Raymond
writers.bio: Portland novelist and screenwriter who co-wrote HBO's Mildred Pierce (Emmy-nominated) and collaborates with filmmaker Kelly Reichardt on Old Joy, Wendy and Lucy, and First Cow. His collection Livability won the Oregon Book Award.

writers.name: Joy Katz
writers.bio: Pittsburgh poet and former Stegner Fellow who transitioned from industrial design to poetry. Her collection All You Do Is Perceive was a National Poetry Series finalist. Co-edited Dark Horses: Poets on Overlooked Poems.

writers.name: Julia Elliott
writers.bio: South Carolina fiction writer whose story collection The Wilds was a New York Times Editors' Choice. Her novel The New and Improved Romie Futch blends Southern Gothic with dystopian satire.
notableWorks: The New and Improved Romie Futch

writers.name: Julian May
writers.bio: Pioneering science fiction author who chaired the first worldcon led by a woman (1952). Her Saga of Pliocene Exile series blends time travel with Celtic mythology. Lived in Oregon from the 1970s until her death.

writers.name: Karla Kelsey
writers.bio: Experimental poet whose A Conjoined Book weaves lyric with philosophy. Editor of Lost Writings: Two Novels by Mina Loy for Yale University Press. Her first book won the Sawtooth Poetry Prize.

writers.name: Katherine Dunn
writers.bio: Portland novelist whose cult classic Geek Love was a National Book Award finalist and has been named one of the Great American Novels by The Atlantic. She taught creative writing at Lewis & Clark College and wrote extensively about boxing.

writers.name: Katrina Porteous
writers.bio: Scottish poet and historian based on the Northumberland coast. Her collection Rhizodont won the 2025 Laurel Prize and was shortlisted for the T.S. Eliot Prize. She writes in both English and Northumbrian dialect.

writers.name: Kaui Hart Hemmings
writers.bio: Hawaii-born novelist whose debut The Descendants was adapted into an Oscar-winning film starring George Clooney. A former Stegner Fellow, she descends from both Hawaiian royalty and American missionaries.

writers.name: Kevin Prufer
writers.bio: Named 2026-2027 Texas Poet Laureate. His collection Churches was named one of ten best poetry books of the year by The New York Times, and How He Loved Them was longlisted for the Pulitzer Prize.

writers.name: Kim Stafford
writers.bio: Oregon's 9th Poet Laureate (2018-2020) and son of Poet Laureate William Stafford. Founding director of Lewis & Clark College's Northwest Writing Institute, where he has taught since 1979.

writers.name: Laurel Nakanishi
writers.bio: Hawaii-born poet and educator. Her collection Ashore was published by Tupelo Press. She directs Hawaii Open Arts and has received grants from the Fulbright Foundation and NEA.

writers.name: Lawson Fusao Inada
writers.bio: Oregon's 5th Poet Laureate (2006-2010) and Japanese American poet interned during WWII. Co-edited the landmark anthology Aiiieeeee!, which helped establish Asian American literature as a field.

writers.name: Layli Long Soldier
writers.bio: Oglala Lakota poet whose debut Whereas won the National Book Critics Circle Award and was a National Book Award finalist. The collection responds to the U.S. government's 2009 apology to Native Americans.

writers.name: Lee Montgomery
writers.bio: Founding editorial director of Tin House Books and executive editor of Tin House magazine. Her memoir The Things Between Us won the Oregon Book Award, and her story collection Whose World Is This? won the Iowa Short Fiction Award.
awards: John Simmons Iowa Short Fiction Award

writers.name: Linda Bierds
writers.bio: MacArthur Fellow (1998) known for elegant historiographic poetry. Taught at University of Washington for over 30 years and her collection Roget's Illusion was longlisted for the National Book Award.

writers.name: Lisa Wells
writers.bio: Portland poet and essayist whose collection The Fix won the Iowa Poetry Prize. Her nonfiction book Believers was a finalist for the PEN E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award.
notableWorks: Believers: Making a Life at the End of the World

writers.name: Lois Leveen
writers.bio: Portland historical novelist. Her debut The Secrets of Mary Bowser was named one of The Oregonian's Top Ten Northwest Books, and Juliet's Nurse became an international bestseller. She has taught at Reed College.

writers.name: Major Jackson
writers.bio: Poetry Editor of The Harvard Review and 2023 inductee to the Academy of Arts & Sciences. His debut Leaving Saturn won the Cave Canem Poetry Prize, and he received an Academy of American Poets fellowship.

writers.name: Marian Pierce
writers.bio: Portland fiction writer and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate who received the James Michener Fellowship. Her collection Finding Land: Stories of Japan draws on her experience working for Japan's National Public Radio.

writers.name: Marianne Boruch
writers.bio: Founded Purdue's MFA program and taught there for 31 years. Her collection The Book of Hours won the $100,000 Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award, one of the largest poetry prizes in the U.S.

writers.name: Marilyn Chin
writers.bio: Pioneering Asian American feminist poet who grew up in Portland after emigrating from Hong Kong. Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets and winner of the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize.
notableWorks: A Portrait of the Self as Nation

writers.name: Marjorie Garber
writers.bio: Harvard Shakespeare scholar and cultural critic. Her book Shakespeare After All was named one of Newsweek's ten best nonfiction books of the year, and Vested Interests: Cross-Dressing and Cultural Anxiety became a landmark in gender studies.

writers.name: Mark Edmundson
writers.bio: University of Virginia professor whose Harper's essay 'On the Uses of the Liberal Arts' became one of the most photocopied essays on American campuses. His book Why Read? argues passionately for literature's power to transform lives.

writers.name: Mark Sarvas
writers.bio: Los Angeles novelist whose Memento Park won the American Book Award and the American Jewish Library Association Fiction Award. Creator of the influential literary blog The Elegant Variation.
awards: American Jewish Library Association Fiction Award

writers.name: Marlena Williams
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark alumna (BA '14) and Portland writer. Her essay collection Night Mother: A Personal and Cultural History of the Exorcist is a 2025 Oregon Book Award finalist.
notableWorks: Night Mother: A Personal and Cultural History of the Exorcist

writers.name: Martin Harries
writers.bio: UC Irvine professor specializing in twentieth-century theater and modernism. His book Theater After Film examines how postwar theater remade itself in response to cinema and mass culture.

writers.name: Marvin Bell
writers.bio: Iowa's first Poet Laureate and creator of the Dead Man poems. Taught at the Iowa Writers' Workshop for 40 years, mentoring Pulitzer winners Rita Dove, Jorie Graham, and Joy Harjo.
notableWorks: Incarnate: The Collected Dead Man Poems
The Book of the Dead Man

writers.name: Mary Bisbee-Beek
writers.bio: Portland-based book publicist and marketing consultant with over 35 years in publishing. Teaches in Portland State's graduate publishing program and advises Ooligan Press.

writers.name: Matt Wagner
writers.bio: Literary agent at Fresh Books Literary Agency specializing in nonfiction. Previously sold over a thousand books at Waterside Productions. UC Santa Cruz graduate in Creative Writing.

writers.name: Matthew Korfhage
writers.bio: Portland native and award-winning food critic who wrote for Willamette Week for a decade. Named best food critic in North America (2017) by the Association of Alternative Newsmedia. Holds an MFA in fiction. Now writes for WIRED.
awards: Best Food Critic in North America (2017)

writers.name: Michael McGriff
writers.bio: Oregon poet raised in Coos Bay whose Eternal Sentences won the 2021 Miller Williams Poetry Prize. Founding editor of Tavern Books and recipient of NEA and Lannan fellowships.
notableWorks: Our Secret Life in the Movies

writers.name: Michael Rankin-Heald
writers.bio: Limited information available. May be a regional or emerging writer.

writers.name: Michele Glazer
writers.bio: Portland poet who directs the MFA program at Portland State University. Her collection fretwork (2021) followed three previous Iowa University Press collections, and she won the Iowa Poetry Prize.
notableWorks: On Tact, & the Made Up World

writers.name: Mohamed Asem
writers.bio: Kuwaiti-American memoirist born in the U.S. and raised in Paris. His memoir Stranger in the Pen, published by Portland's Perfect Day Publishing, chronicles his detention at Gatwick Airport and explores identity across cultures.

writers.name: Molly Antopol
writers.bio: Stanford professor and former Stegner Fellow whose debut collection The UnAmericans was a National Book Award nominee and won the New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award.
awards: New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award

writers.name: Paul K. Saint-Amour
writers.bio: Annenberg Professor in the Humanities and Chair of English at University of Pennsylvania. His book The Copywrights won the MLA Prize for a First Book, and Tense Future won the Matei Calinescu Prize. 2022 Guggenheim Fellow.
notableWorks: Tense Future: Modernism, Total War, Encyclopedic Form
The Copywrights: Intellectual Property and the Literary Imagination
awards: MLA Prize for a First Book

writers.name: Paul Merchant
writers.bio: Welsh-born poet and translator who was Director of the William Stafford Archives at Lewis & Clark College. His Some Business of Affinity was an Oregon Book Award finalist. Co-edited two books of William Stafford's meditations with Vincent Wixon.

writers.name: Pauls Toutonghi
writers.bio: Professor of English at Lewis & Clark College. His memoir Dog Gone was adapted into a 2023 Netflix film. His novels include Red Weather and Evel Knievel Days. Married to novelist Peyton Marshall.

writers.name: Peter Ames Carlin
writers.bio: Lewis & Clark College graduate (1985) and Portland-based biographer. His New York Times bestseller Bruce was the first Springsteen biography written with the artist's cooperation. Also authored biographies of Paul Simon, Brian Wilson, and R.E.M.
notableWorks: Homeward Bound: The Life of Paul Simon

writers.name: Peyton Marshall
writers.bio: Reed College and Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate whose debut novel Goodhouse was a Dashiell Hammett Prize finalist. She received an NEA Prose Writing Fellowship (2022-23) and lives in Portland with her husband, novelist Pauls Toutonghi.

writers.name: Rebecca Clarren
writers.bio: Portland journalist and 2021 Whiting Nonfiction Grant winner. Her book The Cost of Free Land won the 2025 Oregon Book Award (Frances Fuller Victor Award). Has written investigative stories about the American West for over twenty years.
notableWorks: The Cost of Free Land: Jews, Lakota and an American Inheritance

writers.name: Rick Barot
writers.bio: Filipino American poet born in the Philippines, raised in the San Francisco Bay Area. Poetry editor of New England Review and director of Pacific Lutheran University's Rainier Writing Workshop MFA program.

writers.name: Rob LaZebnik
writers.bio: Harvard Lampoon alumnus and longtime writer/co-executive producer on The Simpsons. Has won five Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Animated Program. His episode 'The Burns Cage' marked Smithers' coming out.

writers.name: Ryan White
writers.bio: Portland music critic and journalist who spent nearly 16 years at The Oregonian. Twice named one of the top feature writers in the country by the Society for Features Journalism. Author of books on Jimmy Buffett and Bruce Springsteen.
notableWorks: Jimmy Buffett: A Good Life All the Way

writers.name: Samiya Bashir
writers.bio: First Black woman to receive the Joseph Brodsky Rome Prize in Literature. Her collection Field Theories won the Oregon Book Award. Former Reed College professor; currently June Jordan Visiting Scholar at Columbia.

writers.name: Tess Gallagher
writers.bio: Washington poet, essayist, and playwright born in Port Angeles. Widow of Raymond Carver and literary executor of his estate. Only American to receive the Fondazione Roma lifetime achievement award for poetry (2023).

writers.name: Vern Rutsala
writers.bio: Taught at Lewis & Clark College for over 40 years and helped start its creative writing program with William Stafford. His collection The Moment's Equation was a National Book Award finalist. Won the 2014 C.E.S. Wood Distinguished Writer Award.

writers.name: Vince Wixon
writers.bio: Ashland poet who co-produced documentary films on William Stafford and Lawson Inada. Co-edited two books on William Stafford for University of Michigan Press with Paul Merchant. Helped establish the William Stafford Archives.

writers.name: Vu Tran
writers.bio: Vietnamese American novelist who directs undergraduate creative writing at University of Chicago. His debut novel Dragonfish explores Vietnamese refugees in Las Vegas. Winner of a Whiting Award.

writers.name: Will Aimé
writers.bio: Limited information available. May be a regional or emerging writer.

writers.name: Bill Clegg
writers.bio: Literary agent and author. His debut novel Did You Ever Have a Family was longlisted for the Man Booker Prize. Founder of The Clegg Agency representing major literary fiction authors.
notableWorks: Did You Ever Have a Family
Portrait of an Addict as a Young Man

writers.name: William Deresiewicz
writers.bio: Former Yale English professor and National Book Critics Circle Award winner for reviewing. His bestseller Excellent Sheep critiques elite education; The Death of the Artist examines creative work in the digital age.

writers.name: Youssef Rakha
writers.bio: Egyptian novelist and essayist who writes in both Arabic and English. His first novel The Book of the Sultan's Seal won the Banipal Prize. Selected for Hay Festival Beirut39 as one of the best Arab writers under 40.
notableWorks: The Book of the Sultan's Seal

schema.description: Data structure for each writer entry

fields.name: Full name as it should appear on site
fields.years: Array of years they appeared at L&C
fields.genre: poetry | fiction | nonfiction | criticism (can combine with /)
fields.bio: 1-2 sentences, focusing on significance and connection to literary world
fields.awards: Array of major awards (optional, for notable writers)
fields.wikipediaUrl: Link to Wikipedia page if exists, null if not
fields.officialWebsite: Link to author's website if exists, null if not

photo.url: Direct link to image if known
photo.license: CC BY, CC BY-SA, press use, unknown, etc.

fields.confidence: high | medium | low - confidence in data accuracy
